message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings indicate respiratory distress syndrome, a common complication in premature infants due to inadequate surfactant production. Betamethasone, a corticosteroid, is commonly administered antenatally to accelerate surfactant production and reduce the risk of respiratory distress syndrome. None of the other options address this issue.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and x-ray findings suggest respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) which is common in premature infants. Antenatal administration of Betamethasone can speed up lung maturation and prevent RDS. Epinephrine, Thyrotropin-releasing hormone, and Oxytocin have no effect on lung maturation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and x-ray findings suggest respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), which is common in premature infants. Betamethasone is a corticosteroid that can accelerate lung maturity and prevent RDS in premature infants, and is often given to mothers at risk of preterm delivery. None of the other options are used to prevent RDS.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and x-ray findings suggest neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS). Betamethasone, a corticosteroid, can stimulate fetal lung maturation and reduce the risk of NRDS in premature infants. Epinephrine is used for cardiac arrest and anaphylaxis, not for preventing NRDS. Thyrotropin-releasing hormone and oxytocin are not used for preventing NRDS either.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS), which is common in premature infants. Betamethasone is a corticosteroid that can be given to pregnant women at risk of preterm delivery to help mature fetal lungs and prevent NRDS. None of the other options are indicated for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest respiratory distress syndrome, which is commonly seen in premature infants. Antenatal administration of betamethasone has been shown to reduce the incidence of respiratory distress syndrome in premature infants by promoting lung maturation. None of the other options are indicated for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest respiratory distress syndrome, a common complication in preterm newborns. Betamethasone can be given antenatally to accelerate lung development, which could have prevented this condition. Epinephrine is used to treat anaphylaxis and cardiac arrest, thyrotropin-releasing hormone is used to test thyroid function, and oxytocin is used to induce labor.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the x-ray findings suggest respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), which is common in premature infants. Among the options, only Betamethasone is used to accelerate fetal lung maturity and prevent RDS.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The infant's symptoms suggest respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), which is common in premature infants due to underdeveloped lungs. Antenatal administration of Betamethasone, a steroid that promotes fetal lung maturation, can prevent RDS. The other options are not indicated for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and x-ray findings suggest respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), which is common in premature infants due to insufficient surfactant production. Betamethasone is a corticosteroid that can be given antenatally to enhance fetal lung maturation and prevent RDS. None of the other options are indicated for preventing RDS.
